10 influential mathematics papers from the 2010s: 1. "The proof of the weak Goldbach conjecture" by Harald Helfgott (2013) - Helfgott provided a proof for the weak Goldbach conjecture, which states that every odd number greater than 5 can be expressed as the sum of three prime numbers. 2. "Percolation on random graphs with arbitrary degree distributions" by Svante Janson, T. Luczak, and Andrzej Ruciński (2010) - This paper significantly advanced the understanding of percolation theory on random graphs, which has applications in network theory and epidemiology. 3. "Cohomology of groups and algebraic K-theory" by Guoliang Yu (2012) - This paper made significant contributions to the field of algebraic K-theory and its connections to the geometry of groups, advancing our understanding of the Novikov conjecture and related topics in geometric group theory. 4. "The Kadison-Singer problem in discrepancy theory" by Adam Marcus, Daniel Spielman, and Nikhil Srivastava (2013) - This paper resolved the long-standing Kadison-Singer problem, which has implications for signal processing, operator theory, and discrepancy theory. 5. "A proof of the Sensitivity Conjecture" by Hao Huang (2019) - Huang's elegant and simple proof of the Sensitivity Conjecture in theoretical computer science garnered significant attention for its implications in Boolean function complexity. 6. "On the existence of free 2-generated groups of intermediate growth" by Rostislav Grigorchuk (2018) - Grigorchuk's paper contributed to the understanding of group theory and the growth of finitely generated groups. 7. "The Cap Set Problem" by Ernie Croot, Vsevolod F. Lev, and Péter Pál Pach (2016) - This paper introduced a new algebraic technique that led to a breakthrough in combinatorics, specifically in solving the cap set problem. It provided an improved upper bound on the size of cap sets in high-dimensional vector spaces over finite fields, which had implications for other areas of mathematics and computer science. 8. "Finiteness of classifying spaces of proper G-actions for certain infinite discrete groups G" by Arthur Bartels and Wolfgang Lück (2016) - This paper made significant contributions to algebraic topology and geometric group theory by examining the classifying spaces for proper group actions. 9. "Moduli spaces of polarized K3 surfaces in mixed characteristic" by A. J. de Jong and C. Schoen (2017) - This work in algebraic geometry advanced the understanding of the moduli spaces of K3 surfaces, with implications for arithmetic geometry. 10. "Quantum Error Correction for Qubit Loss Using a Lattice of Qubits" by Daniel Gottesman (2010) - Gottesman's paper on quantum error correction has been influential in the field of quantum computing, providing methods to protect quantum information from errors due to qubit loss. Sources: AIs and Humans AIFI - Artificial Intelligence Finance Institute

10 Influential Mathematical Papers 2000s ( 41-50 ) : 41. Emmanuel Candès, Terence Tao: "Near-Optimal Signal Recovery From Random Projections: Universal Encoding Strategies?" (2006) Introduced the theory of compressed sensing, revolutionizing signal processing and data acquisition. 42. Gérard Laumon, Bao Châu Ngô: "Le lemme fondamental pour les groupes unitaires" (2004) Made significant progress on the Fundamental Lemma, a key component of the Langlands program. 43. Mikhail Gromov: "Entropy and Isoperimetry for Linear and Non-Linear Group Actions" (2008) Advanced the understanding of entropy in geometric group theory and dynamical systems. 44. Michael Freedman, Alexei Kitaev, Michael Larsen, Zhenghan Wang: "Topological Quantum Computation" (2003) Laid the theoretical foundations for topological quantum computing, bridging quantum physics and topology. 45. Claire Voisin: "On the Chow Ring of Certain Algebraic Hyper-Kähler Manifolds" (2004) Made significant contributions to algebraic geometry, particularly in the study of algebraic cycles on hyper-Kähler manifolds. 46. Akshay Venkatesh: "Sparse Equidistribution Problems, Period Bounds and Subconvexity" (2007) Advanced techniques in analytic number theory, particularly in the study of L-functions and equidistribution problems. 47. Alexander Razborov: "Resolution Lower Bounds for Perfect Matching Principles" (2002) Provided new lower bounds in proof complexity, advancing our understanding of the limits of certain proof systems. 48. Assaf Naor, Gideon Schechtman: "Planar Earthmover is Not in L1" (2007) Resolved a long-standing problem in metric geometry and computer science related to the embedding of the earthmover distance. 49. Kiran Kedlaya: "Counting Points on Hyperelliptic Curves using Monsky-Washnitzer Cohomology" (2001) Developed efficient algorithms for counting points on curves over finite fields, with applications to cryptography. 50. Stanislaw Smirnov: "Critical Percolation in the Plane: Conformal Invariance, Cardy's Formula, Scaling Limits" (2001) Proved Cardy's formula for critical percolation, establishing conformal invariance in this model and connecting probability theory with conformal field theory. Source : AIs and Humans

10 influential mathematical papers from 2000s ( 31- 40 ): 31. Irit Dinur: "The PCP Theorem by Gap Amplification" (2007) Provided a new, simpler proof of the PCP Theorem, a fundamental result in computational complexity theory. 32. Terry Tao, Van Vu: "Additive Combinatorics" (2006) This influential book was published in 2006 and had a significant impact on the field of additive combinatorics. 33. Wendelin Werner: "Random Planar Curves and Schramm-Loewner Evolutions" (2004) Developed the theory of SLE (Schramm-Loewner Evolution), a powerful tool for studying two-dimensional random processes. 34. Oded Schramm: "Conformally Invariant Scaling Limits: An Overview and a Collection of Problems" (2006) Surveyed and advanced the field of conformally invariant random processes, particularly SLE. 35. Kannan Soundararajan: "Small Gaps Between Prime Numbers" (2007) Made significant progress on understanding the distribution of small gaps between prime numbers. 36. Terence Tao: "A Quantitative Ergodic Theory Proof of Szemerédi's Theorem" (2006) Provided a new proof of Szemerédi's theorem using ergodic theory, connecting different areas of mathematics. 37. Subhash Khot: "On the Power of Unique 2-Prover 1-Round Games" (2002) Introduced the Unique Games Conjecture, which has had significant impact on computational complexity theory. 38. Jean Bourgain, Nets Katz, Terence Tao: "A Sum-Product Estimate in Finite Fields, and Applications" (2004) Developed new techniques in additive combinatorics with applications to number theory and theoretical computer science. 39. Monika Ludwig, Matthias Reitzner: "A Classification of SL(n) Invariant Valuations" (2009) Advanced the field of convex geometry by classifying SL(n) invariant valuations. 40. Martin Hairer: "An Introduction to Stochastic PDEs" (2009) Laid groundwork for his later work on regularity structures, providing new tools for analyzing stochastic partial differential equations. Source: AIs and Humans AIFI - Artificial Intelligence Finance Institute

10 Influential Mathematical papers from the 2000s - 11 to 20: 11. Ali Rahimi, Benjamin Recht: "The Geometry of Random Features" (2008) Introduced random feature maps for kernel machines, significantly impacting machine learning and approximation theory. 12. Daniel Spielman, Shang-Hua Teng: "Smoothed Analysis of Algorithms: Why The Simplex Algorithm Usually Takes Polynomial Time" (2001) Introduced smoothed analysis, a framework for understanding why the simplex algorithm performs efficiently in practice despite its worst-case exponential time complexity. This work bridged theoretical computer science and practical algorithm design. 13. László Lovász, Balázs Szegedy: "Limits of Dense Graph Sequences" (2006) Developed a theory for graph limits, providing a new framework for understanding large networks and graph sequences. This work has applications in combinatorics, computer science, and statistical physics. 14. Elon Lindenstrauss: "Invariant Measures and Arithmetic Quantum Unique Ergodicity" (2006) Proved the Arithmetic Quantum Unique Ergodicity conjecture for compact arithmetic surfaces, significantly advancing the understanding of quantum chaos and ergodic theory. 15. Elchanan Mossel, Ryan O'Donnell, Krzysztof Oleszkiewicz: "The Gaussian Noise Stability Problem" (2005) Solved a long-standing conjecture about noise stability of boolean functions, with applications in theoretical computer science, social choice theory, and discrete mathematics. 16. Shlomo Hoory, Nathan Linial, Avi Wigderson: "Expander Graphs and Their Applications" (2006) Provided a comprehensive survey on expander graphs, highly influential in theoretical computer science, cryptography, and pure mathematics, particularly in spectral graph theory and group theory. 17. Richard Hamilton: "The Formation of Singularities in the Ricci Flow" (2003) Extended the theory of Ricci flow, providing insights into the formation of singularities and contributing to the proof of the Poincaré Conjecture. This work is fundamental in geometric analysis. 18. Terence Tao: "An Uncertainty Principle for Cyclic Groups of Prime Order" (2005) Established fundamental results in additive combinatorics, with applications to number theory and harmonic analysis. 19. Gregory F. Lawler, Oded Schramm, Wendelin Werner: "Conformal Invariance of Planar Loop-Erased Random Walks and Uniform Spanning Trees" (2004) Proved that loop-erased random walks and uniform spanning trees in the plane are conformally invariant in the scaling limit. This result is a cornerstone in the field of random planar structures and has connections to statistical mechanics. 20. Jacob Fox, Benny Sudakov: "Induced Ramsey-Type Theorems" (2009) Extended classical Ramsey theory to induced subgraphs, providing new results and techniques in extremal combinatorics. This work has applications in graph theory and theoretical computer science. Source: AIs and Humans AIFI - Artificial Intelligence Finance Institute

10 Influential Mathematical papers from the 2000s: 1. Grigori Perelman: "The Entropy Formula for the Ricci Flow and its Geometric Applications" (2003) Proved the Poincaré Conjecture, a fundamental problem in topology. Used Ricci flow techniques to show that any simply connected, closed 3-manifold is homeomorphic to a 3-sphere. 2. Manindra Agrawal, Neeraj Kayal, Nitin Saxena: "PRIMES is in P" (2002) Presented the first deterministic polynomial-time algorithm for primality testing. Proved that determining whether a number is prime can be done in polynomial time. Revolutionized computational number theory and cryptography. 3. Ben Green, Terence Tao: "The Primes Contain Arbitrarily Long Arithmetic Progressions" (2004) Proved that prime numbers contain arithmetic progressions of arbitrary length. Combined methods from ergodic theory, Fourier analysis, and number theory. Resolved a long-standing conjecture and opened new avenues in additive number theory. 4. Ngô Bảo Châu: "Le lemme fondamental pour les algèbres de Lie" (2009) Proved the Fundamental Lemma, a key component of the Langlands program. Connected diverse areas of mathematics including number theory and representation theory. Earned Ngô the Fields Medal for this. 5. Preda Mihăilescu: "Primary Cyclotomic Units and a Proof of Catalan's Conjecture" (2002) Proved Catalan's Conjecture, a problem open since 1844. Showed that 8 and 9 are the only consecutive perfect powers in integers. 6. Harry Kesten: "The Critical Probability for Bond Percolation on the Square Lattice Equals 1/2" (2003) Rigorously proved a key result in percolation theory. Determined the exact critical probability for bond percolation on a square lattice. 7.Maryam Mirzakhani: "Simple Geodesics and Weil-Petersson Volumes of Moduli Spaces of Bordered Riemann Surfaces" (2006) Developed new techniques for calculating volumes of moduli spaces of Riemann surfaces. Connected ideas from hyperbolic geometry, ergodic theory, and symplectic geometry. Led to her becoming the first woman to win the Fields Medal. 8. László Lovász, Santosh Vempala: "Geometry of Logconcave Functions and Sampling Algorithms" (2006) Advanced understanding of the Kannan-Lovász-Simonovits (KLS) conjecture. Developed new techniques in convex geometry and the study of log-concave distributions. 9. Richard Taylor: "The Sato-Tate Conjecture for Elliptic Curves with Complex Multiplication" (2008) Proved the Sato-Tate Conjecture for a class of elliptic curves. Resolved a key problem in number theory about the distribution of Frobenius traces. 10. Cédric Villani, Clément Mouhot: "On Landau Damping" (2009) Provided a rigorous mathematical treatment of Landau damping in plasma physics. Resolved long-standing questions about the behavior of collisionless plasmas. Combined techniques from partial differential equations, Fourier analysis, and statistical mechanics. Source: AIs and Humans AIFI - Artificial Intelligence Finance Institute

10 Influential Mathematics papers from the 1990s ( 21-30 ) : 21. Percy Deift, Xiaoping Zhou, "A Steepest Descent Method for Oscillatory Riemann-Hilbert Problems: Asymptotics for the MKdV Equation" (1993) Deift and Zhou's paper introduced the steepest descent method for analyzing oscillatory Riemann-Hilbert problems. 22. David Mumford, J.L. Lions, and Henri Brezis, "Analysis and Control of Elliptic-Hyperbolic Systems" (1994) This paper addresses the analysis and control of systems that exhibit both elliptic and hyperbolic behavior, contributing to the broader understanding of partial differential equations. 23.Clifford Taubes, "The Seiberg-Witten Invariants and Symplectic Forms" (1994) Taubes' work on the relationship between Seiberg-Witten invariants and symplectic forms has had a profound impact on the study of 4-manifolds and symplectic geometry. 24. Noga Alon and Joel H. Spencer, "The Probabilistic Method" (1992) Alon and Spencer's book has become a fundamental reference in combinatorics, introducing probabilistic techniques that have been widely applied in various areas of mathematics. 25. Jean-François Le Gall, "The Brownian Snake and Solutions of $\Delta u = u^2$ in a Domain" (1997) Le Gall's work on the Brownian snake and its applications to partial differential equations has provided new methods for understanding complex probabilistic and analytic problems. 26. John Conway and Neil Sloane, "Sphere Packings, Lattices and Groups" (1993) This influential book by Conway and Sloane provides a comprehensive study of sphere packings, lattices, and their connections to group theory, impacting multiple areas in mathematics and physics. 27. David R. Morrison, "Mirror Symmetry and Rational Curves on Quintic Threefolds: A Guide for Mathematicians" (1996) Morrison's paper serves as a bridge between mathematics and string theory, providing important insights into mirror symmetry and its mathematical implications. 28. Richard Hamilton, "The Formation of Singularities in the Ricci Flow" (1995) Hamilton's work on Ricci flow has been fundamental to the proof of the Poincaré Conjecture, providing key techniques for understanding the formation of singularities in geometric evolution equations. 29. Don Zagier, "Polylogarithms, Dedekind Zeta Functions and the Algebraic K-Theory of Fields" (1991) Zagier's paper explores deep connections between polylogarithms, zeta functions, and algebraic K-theory, contributing to the understanding of special values of L-functions. 30.Pierre-Louis Lions, "Viscosity Solutions of Fully Nonlinear Second-Order Equations" (1992) Lions' work on viscosity solutions has had a significant impact on the study of fully nonlinear partial differential equations, providing robust techniques for solving complex mathematical problems. Source: AIS and Humans AIFI - Artificial Intelligence Finance Institute
